node.text:
Still I rise... On June 19, 1865, US Brigadier General Gordon Granger and his troops landed at Galveston, Texas, confirming the news that the Civil War had ended and that enslaved African Americans were now free. #Juneteenth commemorates this important milestone. Although the ratification of the 13th Amendment in December 1865 ultimately abolished slavery, the struggle for equality continues today. Through the lens of our nation’s iconic places, the National Park Service has a responsibility to advance understanding of our nation’s unique and complex history. We invite you to watch “Twenty & Odd,” which builds on the innumerable contributions of African Americans to the foundation of the nation and explores the trauma, resilience, and beauty of the African American experience.

#FindYourPark #NationalParkService

node.text:
Set against 400 years of suffering, healing, and strength, with a backdrop of our nation’s most storied lands, the innumerable contributions of African Americans to the foundation of the United States are recognized in this short film.

#TwentyandOdd #NationalParkService #AfricanAmericanHistory #FindYourPark #StillIRise

node.title: Twenty & Odd: 400 Years of African American Experience

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by National Park Service in Hawai'i Volcanoes National Park. May be an image of nature.

node.text:
When someone says you should smile more often…⁣
⁣
Fake smile? Maybe. The Hawaiian happyface spider (Theridion grallator) is endemic to the Hawaiian archipelago, and is only found on four of the islands: Oʻahu, Molokaʻi, Maui, and Hawaiʻi. In Hawaiian, it’s called nananana makaki’i, which translates literally as face-painted spider. Why the happy face? Some theories say the markings deter or confuse predators. (Everything is fine!) The markings may also work as camouflage. The happyface spider lives beneath the leaves of plants (ʻōhiʻa, kōpiko, kāwaʻu) in wet forests at mid-elevations.⁣
⁣
Image: I can’t fake another smile. Never mind. Close up of happyface spider sitting on a green leaf. NPS/Michael Newman @hawaiivolcanoesnps ⁣
⁣
#FindYourPark #spiders #haveaniceday #dontworrybehappyy #hawaii

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by National Park Service in Timucuan Ecological & Historic Preserve / Fort Caroline National Memorial. May be an image of ocean and nature.

node.text:
Would you rather sail, hike, or fish in Timucuan Preserve?⁣
⁣
Located near Jacksonville, Florida, you can visit one of the last unspoiled coastal wetlands on the Atlantic Coast. Cultural and natural resources have a shared history of over 6,000 years within the Timucuan Ecological and Historic Preserve. The interaction between nature and humans is evident…from the spoil islands to the altered wetlands, from the shell middens of the Timucua to the tabby structures of Kingsley Plantation, and from the boat docks of neighboring subdivisions to the introduction of exotic animals and plants. The Timucuan Ecological and Historic Preserve is a place where natural and cultural resources connect.⁣
⁣
These are popular activities in the waters and trails of Timucuan Preserve. While practicing your favorite form of recreation in accessible areas of the preserve, please remember to stay safe and #RecreateResponsibly.⁣
⁣
Image: A sailboat glides on the water next to a shoreline of marsh and trees. NPS/R. Rasmussen⁣
⁣
#florida #jacksonville #timucuanpreserve #recreation #nationalparkservice

location.name: Timucuan Ecological & Historic Preserve / Fort Caroline National Memorial

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by National Park Service in Katmai National Park & Preserve. May be an image of nature.

node.text:
“It's a bold strategy, Cotton. Let's see if it pays off for 'em.” Pepper Brooks⁣⁣
⁣⁣
Ooooh…that splash could be a factor. Good try. Diving is a fishing technique that most bears do not use. However, at the mouth of the Brooks River or even in the jacuzzi (think highly coveted 'plunge pool’), you might see a bear completely submerge seeking fish. On days when many salmon are migrating in the river (some journeys of a thousand miles end badly), a large and dominant male bear will sometimes catch and eat more than 30 fish per day. Salmon are a high calorie meal for a bear. A sockeye salmon contains about 4500 calories, but the fattiest parts of the fish contain the most calories proportionally. Bears know this and prefer to eat the skin, brain, and eggs—the fattiest parts of a salmon—when fish are in abundance. This is an ephemeral behavior, however. When salmon are not abundant or hard to catch then bears will not be as selective and will most often eat the whole fish.⁣⁣
⁣
Have you been watching the bear cams? ⁣Visit explore.org! 
⁣⁣
Image: A light-colored brown bear dives (pounces? trips? Knows exactly what it’s doing?) in a river at Alaska’s @katmainpp. NPS/M. Bradburn ⁣⁣
⁣⁣
#bear #olympics #fishing #alaska #diving #bigsplash #nationalparkservice

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by National Park Service on July 28, 2021. May be an image of one or more people, people standing and outdoors.

node.text:
Before the National Park Service was established in 1916, the @usarmy was responsible for protecting and stewarding the first national parks. In the late 19th and early 20th centuries, African American Army troops, who came to be known as Buffalo Soldiers, played key roles in the development of the national park system, where they patrolled the backcountry, built trails, prevented poaching, and served in the roles later assumed by park rangers. ⁣
⁣
The Buffalo Soldiers served as park stewards in @yosemitenps, @sequoiakingsnps, @glaciernps, and @hawaiivolcanoesnps. Additionally, the legacy of the Buffalo Soldiers is recognized at @charlesyoungnps (Charles Young Buffalo Soldiers National Monument) in Ohio, which preserves the home of Col. Charles Young (1864-1922). Col. Young, a distinguished officer in the United States Army, was the third African American to graduate from West Point and the first to achieve the rank of colonel. He was also the first African American to serve as a superintendent of a national park.
⁣
Image 1: Historic photo of a the 24th Infantry of Buffalo Soldiers that carried out mounted patrol duties in Yosemite. ca. 1899.⁣
⁣
Image 2: Portrait of Col. Charles Young, 1919.⁣
⁣
#BuffaloSoldiersDay #nationalparkservice #otd #buffalosoldiers

location.name: Charles Young Buffalo Soldiers National Monument

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by National Park Service on July 28, 2021. May be an image of one or more people, people standing and outdoors.
Photo by National Park Service on July 28, 2021. May be an image of 1 person.
Photo by National Park Service on July 27, 2021.

node.text:
Croaking device...engaged.⁣
⁣
The gray tree frog's scientific name is Hyla versicolor, which comes from the Latin for "variable color." It is named for its ability to alter its skin color based on the time of day and surrounding temperature. Its upper body has a blotchy pattern that resembles lichen. Although the pattern varies, it usually features two dark central patches, which can be green, buff or gray. This frog occupies a variety of wooded habitats and can be frequently found in forests, hollowed trees, or areas with high “tachyon” emissions. ⁣
⁣
Image: A Gray Tree frog camouflaged against masonry grout at Iowa’s Effigy Mounds National Monument Visitors Center. NPS/K. Moris ⁣
⁣
#frog #graytreefrog #effigymounds #iowa #naturephotography #camoflauge

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by National Park Service on July 27, 2021.
Photo by National Park Service on July 27, 2021.
Photo by National Park Service in Adams National Historical Park. May be an image of outdoors and indoor.

node.text:
Adams National Historical Park is located in Quincy, Massachusetts, approximately ten miles south of Boston. The Park comprises 11 historic structures and a cultural landscape totaling almost 14 acres. The story encompasses five generations of the Adams family (from 1720 to 1927) including two Presidents and First Ladies, three U.S. Ministers, historians, writers and family members who supported and contributed to the success of these public figures.⁣
⁣
The site's main historic features include: John Adams Birthplace, where 2nd U.S. President John Adams was born on October 30, 1735, and less than 75 yards away the John Quincy Adams Birthplace where his son John Quincy Adams, 6th U.S. President was born on July 11, 1767; the "Old House," home to four generations of the Adams family; and the Stone Library containing more than 14,000 historic volumes and including the book collection of John Quincy Adams.⁣
⁣
Image: View of John Adams Birthplace through panes window of neighboring John Quincy Adams Birthplace. @adamsnps ⁣
⁣
#massachusetts #JohnAdams #architecture #historichomes #president #history

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by National Park Service in Channel Islands National Park. May be an image of nature.

node.text:
“I’m Pickle Rick!” ⁣
⁣
Check out this sea pickle. It’s kinda a big dill. Over the past several weeks an abundance of pyrosomes have been spotted in the water and washing up on beaches near California’s Channel Islands. Sometimes called sea pickles, each “tube” is made up of a colony of fast-growing pelagic tunicates rather than a singular animal. Pyrosomes typically live in the open ocean far away from shore but are often carried inland by currents. Pyrosomes, along with salps, are thought to be significant to ocean carbon uptake and sequestration, playing a beneficial role in mediating climate change. Sea pickles also serve as a food source for several kelp forest species such as sea stars, sea urchins, sea anemones, crabs, kelp bass, blacksmith, and opaleye. These amazing creatures can also emit a beautiful bright blue-green bioluminescence that can be seen at night. ⁣
⁣
Thanks to the park’s Kelp Forest Monitoring team for the photo and information. ⁣
⁣
NPS Photo: A pyrosome floats in a kelp forest with the Sea Ranger II just above the surface. ⁣@channelislandsnps
⁣
#underwaterphotography #channelislands #california #sealife #pickle

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by National Park Service in Lake Clark National Park & Preserve. May be an image of nature.

node.text:
This bear is outstanding in its field.⁣
⁣
You go bear! Understanding bear behavior reduces dangerous encounters and benefits both bears and people. What should you be on the lookout for?⁣
⁣
🧸 Bears standing on their hind legs are often trying to gain a better vantage to see or smell something in the distance.⁣
⁣
🧸 Bears walking in a bow legged, "cowboy" stance are expressing dominance, partner. You will see this during the mating season as they try win dominance over other bears and thus the right to mate. It is also used to move others out of prime feeding or resting spots. Git along little dogies.⁣
⁣
🧸 A bear may open its jaws wide in close proximity to another bear's face that it’s trying to impress. Geez, how much salmon did you eat? Nice.⁣
⁣
🧸 Like humans on a video call, yawning can indicate mild irritation. For the good of the order, avoid crowding a bear expressing this behavior. What was that? You’re on mute, Bear. ⁣
⁣
🧸 Huffing, sometimes accompanied by deeper throaty sounds indicates that a bear is nervous. If the bear is directing the huffing at you, it’s time to give the bear more space.⁣
⁣
🧸 Jaw popping/ teeth clacking is a sign that a bear is very agitated and perhaps a little afraid. If you are close enough to hear it, you are too close.⁣
⁣
🧸 A bear that is very agitated may have its ears flattened against its head.⁣
⁣
🧸 A bear that lunges towards you or slaps the ground while playing defense is feeling threatened and telling you to "move away." Take this message very seriously.⁣
⁣
Learn how to stay safe in this environment by becoming familiar with the bear viewing best practices prior to your trip.⁣
⁣
Image: A bear standing upright in a grassy field at @lakeclarknps in Alaska. NPS/A.Jones⁣
⁣
#bear #lakeclarknationalpark #alaska #behavior #nationalparkservice #recreateresponsibly ⁣

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by National Park Service on July 23, 2021. May be an image of one or more people, people standing and outdoors.

node.text:
One bison, two bison, three bison… 🦬⁣
⁣
This week, a team of National Park Service interns with @mosaicsinscience_nps and @lhip_interns headed to Wind Cave National Park to participate in a bison survey and tour the cave as part of #LatinoConservationWeek. During the trip, they learned about the park’s extensive prairie landscape and its wildlife (especially bison and prairie dogs). They also learned about the cave’s discovery, exploration, and its significance as a spiritual place to many.⁣
⁣
The group also helped the park’s wildlife biologist do a count of bison in the park. A regular count helps Wind Cave keep track of how fast the bison population is growing and can monitor the herd to make sure the animals, and their habitat, are protected and conserved for future generations. By the end of the count, between 110 to 130 bison, including 12 calves, were observed. The count was done from a safe distance. Binoculars up! ⁣
⁣
Of the experience, LHIP intern Nicole Segnini said, “This was not only a great educational opportunity for us, but it was also a great way to connect with people who share the same love for nature and conservation and to experience the outdoors like some of us had never done before. Some of us had never even seen a bison, others had never gone camping! This trip also encouraged me to learn more about conservation efforts and wildlife at our parks, and to head outside to discover unfamiliar and unique places and enjoy their beauty and history.” ⁣
⁣
Images: Led by park biologist, a group surveys the landscape and helps count bison at South Dakota’s @windcavenps.⁣ Photos by Shanelle Thevarajah
⁣
#LCW2021 #nationalparkservice #southdakota #windcavenationalpark #bison ⁣

node.text:
Hey @tsa, we saw your recent post. What kind of trees are those? Hopefully, a last minute gate change didn’t lead to an awkward dismount…⁣
⁣
If airport lounging is not your thing, some good places to “sway and chill” are @glaciernps, @craterlakenps, and @hawaiivolcanoesnps. Although hammocks are allowed in most national parks, keep in mind that each park has specific guidelines for hammock use. That may include hammocks only being allowed in developed campgrounds or requiring you to use a stand. (Support trees by supporting yourself!) We always recommend checking a park’s website, or asking a park ranger, before attempting the “Is anyone watching, this is not going to be graceful!” maneuver when getting into a hammock. If attaching to trees, pick a sturdy pair, and think about using padding between the hammock straps and the trees to prevent any damage. Otherwise, enjoy the breeze and good luck getting out…oh, ugh, careful…don’t fight it. This is where you live now. ⁣
⁣
Image: While resting in a hammock, a visitor enjoys the mountain views from Bowman Lake in @glaciernps. Photo by Jacob W. Frank ⁣
⁣
#hammocklife #nationalhammockday #nationalparkservice #tsa #recreateresponsibly #tsanpscollab

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by National Park Service in Yellowstone National Park. May be an image of animal and nature.

node.text:
Can I pet that dog?⁣
⁣
No. Bison calves tend to be born from late March through May and are orange-red in color, earning them the nickname "red dogs." After a few months, their hair starts to change to dark brown and their characteristic shoulder hump and horns begin to grow. Like all wild animals, bison can be dangerous and unpredictable. They are capable of charging and bringing pain who approach too closely. An indicator that a bison may be about to charge is the position of its tail: if it's standing straight up, it's a serious watch-out situation. As with all wildlife, it's important to observe them from a distance.⁣ And don’t pet that dog.
⁣
Image: An adult bison surrounded by three calves “red dogs” standing in the grass at @yellowstonenps. NPS⁣
⁣
#bison #yellowstone #nature #reddog #canipetthatdog

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by National Park Service in Great Smoky Mountains National Park. May be a closeup.

node.text:
I don't alway wear leopard print, but when i do, i'm like a tiger.⁣
⁣
It's #NationalMothWeek! The word "moth" may conjure up images of drab and furry insects sticking to your screen door on a summer night, but moths serve our ecosystem in many ways, including pollination and providing food for many other creatures. The giant leopard moth (Hypercompe scribonia), sometimes referred to as Eyed Tiger Moth, is a beautiful large white moth that is easy to identify. (Hint: Its the spots.) Its wings have a pattern of black and shiny black/blue dots (some solid and some hollow) sprinkled across them. Maybe it should be the Dalmatian moth? Spot on! It has a wingspan of three inches, and when its wings are spread, you can see its colorful abdomen: The top side is iridescent blue with orange markings, while the underside is white with solid black dots. One might think that’s a lot of color and pattern happening, but it works! ⁣
⁣
P.S. When handled or threatened, the Giant leopard moth may release drops of foul-tasting yellow fluid from its thorax to ward off predators. That’s a sure fire way to assure some space. ⁣
